text: hmm hi everyone
Anthony Fantan out here internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review devotion from Jessie where oh
she's there right there and the Wow
really she's over here even on your wall
it's not funny Jessie where is an
up-and-coming pop singer from the UK
this her debut full-length LP my first
exposure to her was singing on that
subtract album last year that I loved
that I thought was so great
she had a vocal appearance on just one
single track then I started hearing
singles and and promotional tracks from
the cell P kind of building up to the
release of the album I ran into 110
percent which has this future garage
style vocal sampling this twittering
busy rhythm some smooth vocals and
synthesizers it has a really bouncy rich
bassline - I didn't really feel like it
was a gripping tune with how it was
delivered it was kind of quiet
throughout not really many climaxes you
know I'm totally for the breaking just
the snapping of traditional song
structures or just adding on them and
experimenting with them but this to me
just feels like no structure but another
single from this LP I love wildest
moments the B is so epic the
presentation of the song period is is
pretty grandiose and I like the lyrics
on the song too about this couple
putting all this effort in sort of
making this relationship work but these
two people in the relationship have a
full understanding of what the potential
for this relationship could be that is
what keeps them going the verse and the
chorus have two very distinct feels to
them really dynamic song the chorus
segues into a beautiful refrain we can
be the greatest we can be the great and
I love how you get that dark choral
effect when Jessie Ware's sings or we
can be the worst of all just kind of
adding that that Moody
to that section of the lyrics because
while these people in this relationship
keep going because they know that
potential of how great this thing could
be they also know that it can be pretty
terrible as well another track that was
put out before this LP sweet talk is
another great pop tune but it has a bit
of vintage feel to a kind of a retro
futuristic going back to the 80s with
the drumbeat and with the synthesizers
and with the guitar leads that kind of
interject between lyrics I like the way
the instrumentation changes on the
second verse maybe the hook could be a
little bit bigger maybe the vocals bite
a bit from little dragon but sweet talk
and wildest moments are like everything
I look for in a pop song this album is
titled devotion and if it is devoted to
anything it is the warm and smooth soul
vibes of artists like Janet Jackson
Whitney Houston Billy ocean Patrice
Rushen
all those names rhymed I think Jesse
where definitely takes influence from
those artists but has a much kind of
killer vibe to her music even though I
thought the singles to this LP were a
little a little hit or miss I was still
pretty excited for this thing thought it
would bring some big things I would get
a very classy kind of pop record however
I feel like once I delved into this
thing from beginning to end all these
small issues that I had on a couple of
the singles just really got amplified
throughout this thing there are a lot of
very underwhelming moments lack of
climaxes and and when Jesse where does
manage to adventure a little bit it can
be a kind of bad experiment like the
first track on here the title track it's
just not a good opener you've got these
twinkling synthesizers and and Jesse is
is vocalizing with some kind of
forgettable lyrics over this groove it
starts off okay but there's not really
any kind of change or significant
progression and the bass line on this
thing is terrible as far as I can tell
the track is in the key of D and and
thing is pretty much in a major scale
except for the baseline which is playing
D and then kind of sliding down to a
second note which if it were going to be
in the D major scale it would be a
diminished sixth but nothing else in the
instrumentation seems to be hinting
toward playing or referencing that
diminished six so it's kind of dissonant
for no real reason there are more tracks
on here that have grooves that are
better than the opener but they two also
kind of lack anything interesting in
terms of progression and what hurts them
even more is that the lyrics here and
there can be pretty amateur or
monotonous I feel like you definitely
could make the case that this is a
sophisticated pop record this pop record
has a very expensive dress on it sips
wine delicately it's not bubblegum by
any means whatsoever but despite the
sophistication I actually think most of
this album is underdeveloped and pretty
weakly improvised thankfully toward the
middle of the LP another solid pop track
with a structure comes out to play
nightlight though the hook is pretty big
I like the strings on the song - nice
production the lyrics can be so cheesy
that it's a song I kind of hate to love
though much of this album is very chill
very fragile and relaxed the ending
tracks seem to get even quieter and and
sadly to me it only adds up to even more
underwhelming moments overall for me
devotion is is really really spotty it
puts forth an image and an attitude that
would make you think that the album is
more progressive than it really is
I am totally down for embracing the past
but Jessie ware doesn't really do
anything new with it or adventurous with
it and I don't think she's put forth the
effort to avoid the pitfalls that kind
of come with this style of music - the
majority of these tracks are heavily
pulling from the kinds of R&B records
that right now are gathering dust in
bins in thrift stores across America I
can see why this album would appeal to
other people more than me
but I didn't like
I mean I'm pretty much sticking to the
singles on this thing and and that's
where my enjoyment of this album really
kind of stops in a big way I'm feeling a
decent too strong for on this thing but
what did you guys think of it did you
love it
did you hate it why and what should I
review next remember the good comment
the great rape but only the strong
subscribe Jessie we're devotion forever
